text: Ratu George Toganivalu (died 17 June 1951) was a Fijian chief and politician. He was Roko Tui of Bua and Ba, and a member of the Legislative Council between 1940 and 1951. ==Biography== During World War I he joined the Māori Battalion and served in France.Death of Fijian leader Pacific Islands Monthly, July 1951, p21 When he returned to Fiji he joined the civil service, becoming Native Assistant Commissioner in Bua. He was subsequently appointed Roko Tui of the province in 1928, succeeding his father Deve.Timothy J. MacNaught (1982) The Fijian Colonial Experience Australian National University, p55 In 1940 Toganivalu was appointed to the Legislative Council. During World War II he was a captain in the Labour Battalion of the Fiji Military Forces. He became Roko Tui of Ba Province in 1946, and was given an OBE in the 1949 New Year Honours. He died in June 1951 in Suva. His sons Julian and William also later served as MPs. ==References== Category:Fijian soldiers Category:New Zealand military personnel of World War I Category:Fijian chiefs Category:Fijian civil servants Category:Members of the Legislative Council of Fiji Category:Fijian military personnel of World War II Category:1951 deaths Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire
